title: John Smith Chipman
text:
John Smith Chipman (August 10, 1800 – July 27, 1869) was a lawyer and politician from the U.S. state of <a href="Michigan">Michigan</a>.
Chipman was born in <a href="Shoreham%2C%20Vermont">Shoreham, Vermont</a>, a son of Barnabas and Polly (Smith) Chipman. He attended the rural schools and graduated from <a href="Middlebury%20College">Middlebury College</a> in 1823. He <a href="reading%20law">studied law</a>, was <a href="Admission%20to%20the%20bar%20in%20the%20United%20States">admitted to the bar</a>, and practiced in <a href="Addison%20County%2C%20Vermont">Addison County, Vermont</a> and <a href="Essex%20County%2C%20New%20York">Essex County, New York</a>.
In 1838, he moved to <a href="Centreville%2C%20Michigan">Centreville</a> in <a href="St.%20Joseph%20County%2C%20Michigan">St. Joseph County, Michigan</a>, where he held several local offices including serving as a member of the <a href="Michigan%20State%20House%20of%20Representatives">Michigan State House of Representatives</a> in 1842. Chipman was elected as a <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Democrat</a> from Michigan's 2nd District to the <a href="Twenty-ninth%20United%20States%20Congress">Twenty-ninth Congress</a>, serving from March 4, 1845 to March 3, 1847. After the end of his term, he moved to <a href="Niles%2C%20Michigan">Niles</a> in <a href="Berrien%20County%2C%20Michigan">Berrien County, Michigan</a>, and later, in 1850, he moved to <a href="San%20Francisco%2C%20California">San Francisco, California</a>, where he resumed the practice of law. He moved to <a href="San%20Jose%2C%20California">San Jose, California</a>, in 1869 and lived in retirement there until his death. He is interred in <a href="Oak%20Hill%20Memorial%20Park">Oak Hill Cemetery</a> in San Jose.
He was regarded as a brilliant lawyer and a natural orator. Bingham writes that "listening to one of his speeches was like reading one of Cooper's novels." He was over six feet tall with black hair and a dark complexion, giving rise to his nickname, Black Chip.
Family.
In October 1824, Chipman married Frances Larabee. They were the parents of William H. Chipman and Frances C. Chipman.
